In particular, we select several two-digit industries as cases from China's Statistical Yearbooks. As shown in column 1 of Table 1, these industries are large in employment size: they employ more than 1 million workers each and 31 million workers in total in 2010. Most of them are also major exporters, with 29 percent of their sales as exports on average (column 2). To facilitate analysis, we sort these firms by the capital/labor ratio (column 3), which can be viewed as a measure of labor (or capital) intensity or as revealing the level of technology. These variables suggest several interesting associations. First, labor-intensive industries are major exporters with very high export/sales ratios, consistent with the fact that China uses its abundant labor for export industries. Among the seven industries, basic iron and steel has the lowest labor intensity, and its sales are mainly domestic. Second, there is a clear negative association between the capital/ labor ratio (column 3) and unit wage cost (column 6), which is defined as the ratio of wage to value added per worker, suggesting that labor-intensive industries have higher unit labor costs. Finally, the last two columns suggest that labor-intensive industries experienced a sharp rise in unit labor costs. As an example, for the apparel industry, the unit labor cost increased from 0.31 in 1997 (column 5) to 0.41 in 2010 (column 6). The unit labor cost also increased in two other relatively low-tech industries: leather, fur, and other textiles; and electronics (which is mostly assembly). However, industries with higher capital/labor ratios like transport equipment and basic iron and steel experienced a decline in unit labor costs in the same period, suggesting that the labor cost advantage remains for the relatively high-tech industries. ## Potential Reasons for Rising Wages The discussion to this point has argued that China's real wage was more or less stagnant or stable in the 1980s and early 1990s, and grew substantially beginning in the late 1990s. In this section, we discuss three potential reasons for this change: institutional reforms, the disappearing “demographic dividend,” and the slowing of rural-urban migration. ### Institutional Reforms China has transformed its economy from a planned labor allocation system to a more market-oriented labor market. In the planned system, workers were allocated by the central planner to the state-owned enterprises, and jobs were permanent with little mobility (Fleisher and Wang 2004). The central planner set the wages of all workers in the country using a simple system of grades, with the grade mainly depending on seniority. Wages were set low, and so was the wage gap between grades. In this system, wages did not reflect productivity, and because of this and the misallocation of workers, productivity was low. The first major step in China's urban labor market reforms was to establish an internal pay incentive system within state-owned enterprises. Starting in the late 1980s, the financial insolvency of many state-owned enterprises prompted the Chinese government to undertake a series of reforms. The reforms started by allowing profitable firms to pay higher wages and even bonuses to the more productive workers, which increased the pay difference among workers (Park, Song, Zhang, and Zhao 2008). However, because private firms were still not allowed in these areas and job mobility was low, there was essentially no external labor market. ![](images/50adfa70d3d8e5e03d2bdb8b99a99e6b5fd2f98130ba8e277286122d192a1c42.jpg) Figure5 Private Employment as a Proportion of Total Urban Employment Source:China StatisticalYearbooks. The second step in urban labor market reforms was to establish an external labor market. The most aggressive enterprise reforms took place in the mid-to-late 1990s, when China started to privatize state-owned enterprises and when the status of private firms was legalized (Cao, Qian, and Weingast 1999; Li 2003). These reforms were dramatic, with millions of state-owned workers being laid off and moving to jobs in the private sector. At the same time, the government started to allow largescale migration of rural workers to cities (Cai and Wang 2010). Taken as a whole, these reforms established an external labor market that not only helped reallocate workers but also linked wages more closely to productivity (Zhang, Zhao, Park, and Song 2005). With these reforms, the private sector has become a prominent player in the labor market, with private sector employment as a proportion of total urban employment rising from literally nothing in the early 1980s to about 80 percent at present, as shown in Figure 5. One consequence of the labor market reforms is the increase in the return to education, suggesting that the link between wage and productivity is becoming stronger. We replicate Zhang et al. (2005) in calculating a Mincer-style rate of return to education--that is, using wages as a dependent variable, and level of education and work experience as the key explanatory variables--but use the Urban Household Survey sample, which covers more provinces and a longer time series. The results of this calculation, reported in Figure 6, show that the return to an additional year of schooling is only 2.3 percent in 1988, but it increased to about 9 percent in 2000 and has been stable in the past decade. The return to an additional year of education in the latest year of 2009 was 9.5 percent, similar to the world average rate of 9.7 percent, as reported by Psacharopoulos and Patrinos (2004). The return to college education in China increased the fastest, from only about 7.4 percent in the largely planned labor allocation system in 1988 to 49.2 percent in the much more flexible labor market system of 2009, exceeding the average 40 percent return in developed economies. ![](images/42773742e0bb9384ffdd8c70229faf76378a4ca87caa5d429649c64c93ff2ea2.jpg) Figure6 Returns to Education in Urban China Source: Authors’ estimations using data from the Urban Household Survey data in 9 provinces, 1988-2009. ### Demographic Transition and Labor Shortage China has experienced a demographic transition from high to low birthrates since the 1970s. China had a baby boom from 1950 to 1978, with the total fertility rate averaging 5.2 births per woman, although a break occurred during the so-called "Great Leap Forward" from 1958 to 1961, during which around 30 million people died (Ashton, Hill, Piazza, and Zeitz 1984). China's total population increased from 552 million in 1950 to 963 million by 1978. In 1979, China started the “onechild policy,” the largest and strictest population control policy in human history (Banister 1987). According to this policy, still largely in effect today, each woman is allowed to have only one child, and above-quota births are heavily fined. The one-child policy, together with other social and economic changes, has a significant impact on the fertility rate (Li and Zhang 2007; Li, Zhang, and Zhu 2011). China's total fertility rate fell sharply from 6 births per woman in 1970 to only 1.4 in 2010 (TheEconomist 2011). Many countries have experienced lower birthrates as their economies develop, but the speed and magnitude of China's demographic transition are unprecedented in world history. The natural growth rate of China's population has decreased to an annual rate of 0.56 percent since 2001, similar to the population growth rate in Japan from 1980 to 1985. The United Kingdom took about 200 years (1750 to 1955) to complete its demographic transition to having low birthrates, and the United States took 140 years (1800 to 1940) to do the same (Livi-Bacci 1997; Greenwood and Seshadri 2002), while China's transition took only about 30 to 40 years. This rapid shift to lower birthrates creates the “demographic dividend,” that is, a situation in which a disproportionate share of the population is in its prime working years, with relatively few children or elderly. As Chinese baby boomers entered the labor market in the past three decades, China's labor force increased from 583 million in 1980 to about one billion in 2011. The sharply declining fertility of the baby boomers then leads to a low “young dependency ratio" or a large proportion of working-age people. Indeed, the working-age population aged 15-64 increased from 59.3 percent of China's population in 1980 to 74.4 percent in 2011. A large proportion in the work force and a low dependency ratio all tend to be accompanied by a high savings rate, abundant labor, and abundant working time for labor, which are beneficial for economic growth (Li and Zhang 2007). However, the same demographic transition also means that China has entered a period when its labor force will increase much more slowly. Because of the low fertility of the baby boomers, China's labor force growth has been slowing down. As shown in the last section, coinciding with the faster wage growth after 1997, the growth rate of China's labor force dropped from 1.9 percent before 1997 to 1.4 percent since 1997, suggesting that the declining labor force growth could be one of the reasons behind the fast wage growth in the last decade. Based on the “low variant" estimates by the United Nations (201l), China's population is expected to begin declining by 2015, and the labor force may have already peaked in 2011. According to these projections, which assume no upward shift of the birth rate, China's population will decrease from its current level of 1.34 billion to 1.13 billion by 2050, and the working population will decrease from one billion to 696 million. By then, China's labor force as a proportion of the population will drop to 62 percent, whereas the proportion of the elderly (aged 65 and over) will reach 29 percent. The dropping labor force proportion will cause labor shortages and help push wages up further.4 China is already experiencing labor shortages. China's Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security carries out quarterly surveys that cover official job centers in 117 cities. These surveys show that the “position/seeker ratio,” which is the ratio of newly created positions over the number of job seekers, has been trending upward from 0.65 at the start of 2001 to above 1.0 in the first quarter of 2010 and 1.08 in the first quarter of 2012. When the position/seeker ratio exceeded one for the first time in China, the number of newly created jobs exceeded the number of job seekers. The labor shortage phenomenon is especially evident in China's coastal areas, such as the Pearl River Delta and the Yangtze River Delta areas. In the first quarter of 2008, the position/seeker ratio in the Pearl River Delta area reached a historical high of 1.89. Although the ratio dropped during the global financial crisis, it has rebounded with the recovering economy. In the first quarter of 2010, the ratios for the areas of the Pearl River Delta, Southeast Fujian, Yangtze River Delta, and Bohai increased to levels above 1, indicating a labor shortage in most of the coastal regions. Can population growth increase again if China relaxes the one-child policy? This outcome seems unlikely. China is already relaxing the policy by allowing couples who are both an only child to have a second child. The first cohorts of the “one-child policy” children (born in the 1980s) are already in their childbearing age, but the birth rate has shown no sign of recovery so far. The one-child policy, together with many other social and economic reforms, may have caused a lasting change in preferences about fertility in China. There have also been calls for a total removal of all birth control policies, but the government seems hesitant to do so because of political resistance from both the multitude of birth control agencies and the people who were penalized by the one-child policy. ### Slowing Down of Structural Changes The migration of rural workers to urban areas in recent decades has helped keep the wages low in urban areas, but this pattern seems ripe for change as well. According to various Statistical Yearbooks of China, the number of migrant workers increased from 25 million in 1985 to 159 million in 2011. However, the growth rate of migrant workers is slowing down. Using 1997 as the breaking point, the growth rate declined from 10.8 percent per year before 1997 to only about 4.6 percent annually since then. The major barriers to increasing migration from rural areas are a combination of the remaining institutions, such as the hukou system, and the fact that many of those who can migrate at the lowest cost are already doing so. Chinese households are managed by the hukou (household registration) system, which was established in the early 1950s to consolidate socialist governance, control domestic migration, and administer the planned economy. Every person is required to be registered at his/ her place of birth and then acquire a hukou certificate that specifies rural/urban status and location from there. All administrative activities, such as land distribution, issuance of identity cards, registration of a child in school, and medical insurance, are based on hukou status. Until the early 1990s, the hukou was also used to distribute food, cooking oil, and clothing coupons, thus restricting internal mobility in both urban and rural areas. Although the hukou system has been gradually relaxed since the mid-1990s, it still restricts migration in many ways. Farmers have been allowed to migrate to cities to work since the mid-1990s, but they cannot change their hukou status and thus cannot enjoy public services in the cities such as education, medical insurance, housing, and pensions. Unfortunately, most of these public services are of much lower quality or do not even exist in rural areas because most of the government spending is in urban areas. The huge gap in public welfare provision prevents the government from removing the hukou policy, as entrenched urban residents do not want to share their welfare benefits with the migrants, even though they need migrant workers to provide services. A recent proposal to allow migrant children to take the college entrance exams in cities has received heavy resistance from the local residents in Beijing and Shanghai.5 Table2 Proportion of Chinese Rural Residents Working Off-Farm

Various pieces of evidence suggest that the marginal cost of migration is rising. and the distance and need for migration are being shaped by the hukou system. According to de Brauw, Huang, Rozelle, Zhang, and Zhang (2002) and Rozelle, Huang, Zhang, and Li (2008), who conducted three rounds of surveys in China in 1995, 2004, and 2007, most young rural residents no longer worked in agriculture by 20o7. The probability of doing off-farm work for all rural laborers increased from 31 percent in 1995 to 60 percent in 2007. The sharpest increase was observed among the youngest age group of 16-20, for which the probability of working off farm increased from 24 percent in 1995 to 98 percent in 2007, as shown in Table 2. Now, the youngest cohorts of laborers have almost no farmers. Even for older cohorts, the probability of working off farm was very high by 2007: the probability was 87 percent for cohorts aged 21-25 and 77 percent for cohorts aged 26 to 30. As fewer young rural laborers are available, the marginal migrant worker will become older and have a higher marginal cost of migration. Indeed, the average age of migrants is increasing. According to a survey by China's National Bureau of Statistics, the average age of off-farm laborers increased from 34 years in 2008 to 36 years in 2011. The proportion of older off-farm laborers (aged 41 or above) increased from 30 to 38 percent in the same period. Thus, the potential supply is largely tapped out. Migrants are staying closer to home, which helps reduce their migration costs. Again, according to the National Bureau of Statistics, the proportion of migrants working out of the province decreased from 53 percent in 2008 to 47 percent in 2011. The proportion of migrant workers working away from their home provinces decreased most significantly in China's poorest western areas, from 63 to 57 percent in the three-year period. One reason why migrants can remain closer to home is that some factories and laborers are also moving from the coastal to the inland areas because of rising production costs such as labor and land costs, a phenomenon termed “flying geese" by Akamatsu (1962). For instance, Foxconn Technology Group is the largest contract supplier (assembling electronic products by Sony, Apple, Hewlett-Packard, Nokia, and other brand names) in China, employing over a million workers. This company moved its major plants away from Shenzhen to inland provinces such as Hebei and Henan (Luk 2010), mainly because of the hefty wage increases in Shenzhen. However, the migration of firms and workers back to the inland areas is likely to be limited. In fact, Chinese manufacturing industries have been highly concentrated in the coastal areas since the central government established five special economic zones in the coastal areas in the 1980s (Wen 2004), and they have become even more geographically agglomerated in the last decade (Long and Zhang 2012). The agglomeration of industries in the coastal or border areas has occurred in other East Asian countries as well as in the rest of the world (Hanson 1996). One explanation for this phenomenon is the Krugman (1991) lock-in hypothesis, which argues that once industries are concentrated in the coastal regions for whatever reason, and then increasing returns to scale in production occur, more firms are encouraged to locate in these regions to benefit from the backward and forward linkages and from the external economies created. The reduction in China's trade barriers can also facilitate agglomeration in the coastal and border areas (Hanson 2o01). # Conclusion In the 1980s and through the late 1990s, Chinese workers were cheap in the sense that their labor cost relative to productivity was much lower than that of most other countries. Therefore, firms earned rents by sourcing in China, which triggered fast employment growth and rural-urban migration. But because of changes since the late 1990s, including institutional reforms in China's labor markets and demographic transition that have reduced what used to be a huge amount of slack in labor supply, the “underpricing" of Chinese labor appears to be coming to an end. Wages are rising faster than labor productivity, particularly in labor-intensive exporting industries such as apparel and electronics, which will likely move out of China and probably go to countries like India and Vietnam. China is becoming a middle-wage country. If the annual rate of wage growth of 13.8 percent over the past decade is maintained, the average real wage in urban China would reach $\$20,000$ in U.S. dollars by 2020. As benchmarks for comparison, U.S. compensation for manufacturing workers reached $\$20,000$ in 1980, Japanese compensation for manufacturing workers reached this level in 1986, and the annual wage in Korea reached $\$20,000$ in 1995, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. Even if China's wage only grows at par with productivity at 11.3 percent per year, the Chinese average real wage will reach $\$20,000$ by 2022. Similarly to other middle-wage countries, China needs to make a transition toward higher valueadded industries, whether export or domestic. Is China ready to move up the technological ladder? We believe the answer is “yes,” for several reasons. First, China's aggregate labor productivity has been increasing at 11.3 percent per year for over a decade, partly because of manufacturing firms' heavy investment in research and development (with expenditures on research and development per worker increasing at an annual rate of 16.9 percent in the past 20 years) and capital deepening (total assets per worker in China increased to $\$94,240$ in 2010). Second, human capital, at least measured in quantity, has risen dramatically. In 1999, the Chinese government started an aggressive "College Expansion" movement that increased the college entry class enrollment from 1.1 million in 1998 to 6.6 million in 2011. By 2050, Ma (2010) predicts that 40 percent of China's labor force can be expected to hold a college degree, similar to the level of Japan's labor force today. In short, the end of cheap labor in China does not mean the end of Chinese economic growth. Rising productivity and education mean that China's comparative advantage is shifting. If China can improve the quality of education and develop institutions that help to foster innovation and entrepreneurship, then going forward, China may join a place alongside Korea and Japan (with a lag of two decades) as a formidable force in high value-added manufacturing and innovation. # References Akamatsu, Kaname. 1962. “A Historical Pattern of Economic Growth in Developing Countries." In this paper, we investigate the role of the new generation of information technology (IT) in explaining process of structural labor change in China. For the analyses, we develop a general equilibrium model of structural labor change driven by both the new technology and the old technology. We improve the model by distinguishing between these two technologies, introducing the new technology penetration rate, and considering the differences in the production structure. We calibrate the parameters according to China's economic characteristics based on Chinese labor market data from 1978 to 2018 and then design a series of counterfactual experiments. The results show that our benchmark model depicts the dynamic characteristics of China's structural labor changes since the reform and opening-up process. The impact of labor market distortions and structural production differences on changes in the labor reallocation is limited. The progress of the new generation of IT may significantly promote China's structural labor adjustment.  

## 1. Introduction  

The integration of the new generation of information technology (IT) and various sectors has a deep influence on the development of traditional sectors like the agriculture, industry, and services sectors, which prominently manifests the process of structural change. Structural change entails not only changes in output and productivity, but it also shifts the mix of inputs used in the production process (Bartel et al., 2007; Jorgenson and Timmer, 2011). One of the most obvious characteristics is the redistribution of labor across sectors. That is, the share of labor in agriculture has been declining systematically over time, while the share in services has been increasing steadily, and the share of labor in industry increases in the early stages of the redistribution process and then decreases in the later stages. Along the modern paths of development, China has been undergoing a process of structural transformation by which labor is reallocated between agriculture, industry, and services. Fig. 1 illustrates the process of China's structural labor changes. Currently, the rapid development of the new generation of IT is accelerating China's process of structural labor change. So, we cannot ignore their close relationship.  

This issue is central to understanding the structural transformation in the economic development literature, which has been extensively documented (Kuznets, 1971; Duarte and Restuccia, 2010). Most countries are going through a common process of structural transformation, although there are substantial lag differences in this process (Duarte and Restuccia, 2010). We may take China as an example. The transformation of the labor structure during China's rapid economic development has been associated with the substantial but often unnoticed development of the new generation of IT. Our paper analyzes the labor structural adjustment by taking a close look at the impact of emerging IT. We ask the following questions: Does the new generation of IT opti mize the structure of China's labor markets? Through which channel can it play this role? How much it will affect the transformation and upgradingof thelabor structure?  

In this paper, we examine the role of the new generation of IT on the reallocation of labor across sectors. We start our analysis by presenting a general equilibrium model of structural labor market change driven by a new generation of IT, following the early calibration strategy of Duarte and Restuccia (2010). Then, we calibrate the parameters according to China's economic characteristics to explore the role of the IT revolution in the process of structural labor change in China.

Our emphasis on the link between the new generation of IT and structural labor change is supported by observations that the process of the structural transformation has accelerated in recent years, and it is rooted in theoretical analyses. We construct a theoretical model of structural labor change driven by both new and old technology. We improve the model by distinguishing between these two technologies, introducing the new technology penetration rate, and considering differences in the production structures. Our model indicates that the development of the new generation of IT is significantly conducive to changes in the labor structure. The model replicates the basic time trend in sectoral shares of labor observed in the data.  

This paper uses Chinese labor market data from 1978 to 2018 to test our theoretical analysis. The database contains reliable information on China's dynamic characteristics of labor reallocation among three sectors. To fully understand the driving factors of structural labor change, we first distinguish and compare various drivers in the model that resulted in the structural labor adjustment and then test and analyze the role of the different mechanisms of the new generation of IT progress in particular.  

Our empirical results are consistent with our theoretical analysis and are robust across different numerical simulations. By analyzing counterfactual experiments, we come to several conclusions. The significant improvement in the progress rate of new IT will accelerate the process of labor structural adjustment in a short period of time, while the improvement of the progress space of the new IT and the increase of its penetration rate among sectors will promote China's labor structural optimization in the long run, which is characterized by a significant decline in the share of labor in agriculture and a continuous increase in services.  

The causes of structural transformation are actively debated in current development research.The allocation of labor has been discussed since Baumol (1967).Inspired by the early contribution of Baumol (1967), related literature has identified several mechanisms that can drive structural change. The focus of previous literature on structural transformation has been on two channels. One strand of the literature has emphasized the demand-side mechanisms that introduce heterogeneity in the income elasticity of demand between goods (Kongsamut et al., 2001; Foellmi and Zweimiller, 2008; Boppart, 2014); whereas another strand has mostly highlighted the supply-side mechanisms whereby total factor productivity (TFP) differences between sectors play a leading role (Ngai and Pissarides, 2007; Acemoglu and Guerrieri, 2008; Ma0 and Ya0, 2012).  

Our paper is related to studies on the relationship between technological progress, productivity improvement, and structural change. Fagerberg (2000) showed that new technologies play an important role in driving structural change. Ngai and Pissarides (2007) constructed a multisector structural change model and explained the productivity mechanism of structural adjustment by which labor resources will be transferred to sectors with a lower TFP growth rate when the substitution elasticity between final goods is low, while when the elasticity is high, it will be transferred to sectors with a higher TFP growth rate. Duarte and Restuccia (2010) studied structural change by investigating the role of sectoral labor productivity and concluded that a difference in productivity is the only cause of labor reallocation between three sectors under certain assumptions. Mao and Yao (2012) developed a dynamic general equilibrium model to examine structural change in a small open economy and used the productivity effect and the BalassaSamuelson effect to explicate the structural transformation. Swiecki (2017) formalized an argument that sector-based technological change is a vital driver of structural change that can be used to explain the shift of labor from manufacturing to services in the later stages of structural change. Monteforte (2020) developed a small-scale general equilibrium model to investigate the role of sectoral TFP in driving structural change and explains the importance of labor reallocation. Song (2021) studied the factors that drive labor share changes and showed the significant role of technological progress.  

Technological progress can contribute to structural change (Acemoglu, 2002; Desmet et al., 2020), and the advent of emerging technologies may directly substitute inputs (Acemoglu and Autor, 2011). In recent decades, one of the most remarkable technological changes has been the rapid development and wide application of IT, which may have a positive effect on labor productivity (Andersen, 2001). It has also been taken as the driving force of underlying the “productivity resurgence” (Jorgenson et al., 2008). The development of IT may also have an important impact on the labor market and changes in labor demand (Bresnahan et al., 2002). Jorgenson and Vu (2007) allocated the growth of world output between input growth and productivity and found that input growth greatly predominates and that IT investment was an important factor for capital deepening and productivity improvement after 1990s. Further, the contributions of IT investment to productivity are greater than that of physical capital. Basu and Fernald (2007) determined that IT capital is a special factor of production that differs from physical capital and human capital, and US data suggests that industry TFP acceleration is positively correlated with industrial IT capital growth, albeit with a long lag. Dimelis and Papaioannou (2010) indicated that the growth contribution of IT is quite high for both developed and developing countries, while this effect is greater among developing countries. Thus, they argued that IT investment provides a powerful incentive for developing countries to seek a more refined structure for their industrial economies.  

Our study is also connected to the research on information and communication technology (ICT). ICT not only promotes the improvement of labor productivity (Ceccobelli et al., 2012; Martinez et al., 2010), but also spurs economic growth (Schreyer, 2000; Cardona et al., 2013). Many studies have analyzed the impact of ICT on productivity, labor markets, and structural change (Zuhdi et al., 2014; Akerman et al., 2015). Many relevant studies have discussed the effect of computer technology (Oliner et al., 1994; Jorgenson and Stiroh, 1995). With the vigorous development of the mobile internet, cloud computing, big data, and the internet of things (IoT), many studies have placed emphasis on the importance of emerging ICT (Caputo et al., 2016; Del Giudice, 2016; Khan et al., 2020). Hjort and Poulsen (2019) examined how African employment is affected by high-speed internet and found that high-speed internet can shift labor shares toward higher-productivity occupations.  

The existing research provides an important reference for this paper. Despite a revival of interest in estimating the drivers of structural labor change, there has been limited discussion of the new generation of IT. Previous research on IT and structural change has not identified any mechanisms to account for the link between the penetration of $\mathrm{IT}$ progress to TFP and labor reallocation. This paper attempts to fill this gap in the literature by analyzing the quantitative importance of the new generation of IT in the changes in the labor structure.  

Our contribution to the literature is twofold. First, we analyze the impacts of the new generation of IT on labor force reallocation across sectors directly and quantitatively. Our framework departs from existing models (Kongsamut et al., 2001; Ngai and Pissarides, 2007; Duarte and Restuccia, 2010) in assessing the penetration rate of the new generation of IT and in considering different production structures across sectors. Second, we sort out the different mechanisms that resulted in the structural labor change. We broaden the analysis to examine how the structural change is affected by technological progress.  

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 puts forward the theoretical model and describes the key theoretical mechanisms. Section 3 calibrates a benchmark economy with Chinese data for the period between 1978 and 2018. Section 4 discusses the robustness of our model. Section 5 performs counterfactual exercises. Finally, Section6concludes.  

## 2. The model  

This section starts with an analysis of the structural labor change under the background of the rapid development of the new generation of IT in the context of a general equilibrium model of the employment structural transformation driven by this new IT and previous old technology.  

Based on the theoretical model of Duarte and Restuccia (2010), this paper introduces the variables of the new generation of $\mathrm{IT}$ progress and the penetration rate of this new technology. Then, the model of structural labor change driven by the new generation of $\mathrm{IT}$ is constructed. The theoretical model of this paper assumes that the economy consists of agriculture, industry, and services and that each sector produces only agricultural, industrial, and service products in each period. This basic framework captures the significant features of the structural changes that have occurred in China.  

### 2.1.Production with the new generation of IT  

Suppose that there are three goods produced in each period: agriculture (a), manufacturing $(m)$ , and services (s). The production function for each of the three goods is given by the following Cobb-Douglas pro  

duction function with constant returns:  

$$
Y_{i}=A^{\gamma_{i}}A_{i}L_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}K_{i}^{1-\alpha_{i}},i\in\{a,m,s\}
$$  

where $Y_{i}$ is output in sector $i,L_{i},K_{i}$ and $A_{i}$ are the labor and capital inputs, and the original “old technology” except for the new generation of IT in sector i. $\alpha_{i}$ and $(1\mathrm{~-~}\alpha_{i})$ , respectively, represent the contribution of labor and capital to output. $A^{\gamma_{i}}A_{i}$ is sectoral TFP, where $A$ is the new generation of $\mathrm{IT}$ parameter, and $\gamma_{i}$ is sector-specific new generation of IT penetration to sectoral TFP.  

We assume that the total supply of capital is fixed and exogenous. It is helpful for us to focus on the research and analysis of the labor structure change driven by technology, especially for the new generation of IT. The capital-intensive characteristics of different sectors are reflected by $\alpha_{i}$ . Agriculture is land-intensive, manufacturing is capital-intensive, and services are human-capital-intensive.  

We assume that labor and capital are freely mobile across sectors and that factor prices $w$ and $r$ are given. The profit maximization problem of a representative firm can be illustrated by the following static problem:  

$$
\operatorname*{max}_{L\ge0,K\ge0}{\{p_{i}A^{\gamma_{i}}A_{i}L_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}K_{i}^{1-\alpha_{i}}-w L_{i}-r K_{i}\}},
$$  

where $p_{i}$ is the price of good i.  

As the key to our research is to analyze the impact of new and old technological changes on the adjustments in the labor structure of the three sectors, the following settings are made for technical factors:  

#### 2.1.1. The new generation of $I T$  

We assume that the new generation of $\mathrm{IT}$ progress follows the technology diffusion $^{\circ}\mathsf{S}^{\prime}$ curve (Mansfield, 1961; Comin and Mestieri, 2014), whose general expression is as follows:  

$$
A(t)=A_{0}+\frac{A^{*}-A_{0}}{1+e^{-\mu(t-h)}}.
$$  

$A_{0}$ is the initial value of the new technological progress rate, $A^{*}$ is the upper limit of the new technological progress rate, $\mu$ represents the curvature of the change trend of the technological growth rate, $h$ represents the time node of the change trend of the new technological progress rate from convex to concave. The reason for using an ${}^{6}{\mathsf{S}}^{,}$ technology diffusion curve is that the development of new technology usually goes through a relatively gentle initial stage, a high-speed development stage, and a slow mature stage. Conversely, in the early stage of the development of new technology, it has a relatively limited role in promoting the TFP of the three sectors. This is because technological innovation and the transformation and upgrading of production systems are not perfectly matched with the new technology, and its contribution to output is relatively small. With the development of the relevant supporting infrastructure, the popularity of new technology in various sectors will increase rapidly. After reaching a certain degree, with the development of new technology gradually entering the bottleneck period, its contribution to output growth will also tend to be flat. Combining these two features, this paper uses equation (3) to describe the development of the new generation of IT.  

#### 2.1.2. The old technology in each sector  

According to the practice of most studies, we suppose the rate of technological progress is exogenous and constant. It is recorded as $\mu_{i}$  

$$
\frac{\dot{A_{i}}}{A_{i}}=\mu_{i}.
$$  

We also assume that $\mu_{i}>0$ , that is, technological progress, will not stagnate.  

### 2.2. Households  

We assume that the economy consists of an infinitely lived representative household of constant size. The household is endowed with $L$ units of time each period. Then, the representative household obtains utility from the consumption of agricultural products, $c_{a,t},$ and nonagricultural products, $c_{t}$ . The household obtains preferences over consumption goods as follows:  

$$
\sum_{t=1}^{\infty}\beta^{t}u(c_{a,t},c_{t}),\beta\in(0,1)
$$  

The per-period utility is given by the following:  

$$
u(c_{a,t},c_{t})=a\log(c_{a,t}-\overline{{a}})+(1-a)\log(c_{t}),
$$  

where $a\in(0,1)$ and $\overline{{a}}>0$ is the subsistence level of agricultural goods below which the household cannot survive. This feature of household preferences can lead to the movement of labor away from agriculture in the process of structural transformation. Numerous studies have attached great importance to this feature of preferences, and it has been considered as a quantitatively significant feature that may lead to the shift of labor from the agricultural sector during the process of structural change (Kongsamut et al., 2001; Gollin et al., 2002). The consumptionweight, $a_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathrm{(}}$ .of agricultural products is generally small. It can be seen from equation (6) that the elasticity of substitution between agricultural and non-agricultural products is relatively low, that is, agricultural products cannot be replaced by other products.  

The consumption quantity of non-agricultural products, $c_{t}.$ canbe expressed as a constant elasticity of substitution utility function as follows:  

$$
c_{t}=[b c_{m,t}^{\rho}+(1-b)(c_{s,t}+\overline{{s}})^{\rho}]^{\frac{1}{\rho}}
$$  

$c_{m,t}$ and $c_{s,t}$ represent the consumption of a representative household of industrial products and service products, respectively, $\overline{{s}}>0$ is the fixed level of service products that households can provide, and $b\in(0,1)$ $\rho\:<\:1$ . In equation (7), $\overline{{s}}>0$ means that the income elasticity of product demand for services is greater than one. When the household's income level is low, the number of production factors allocated to services is lower. On the contrary, when the household income level increases, more production factors will be allocated to services. The symbol $\rho$ determines the substitutability between industrial and service products. When $0~<~\rho~<~1$ , the substitutability between industrial and service products is greater, when $\rho~<~0$ , the substitutability between the two is lower. When the prices of the three industrial products are given, households can maximize their utility by choosing a consumption portfolio consisting of different products.  

In each period, the household chooses the consumption of each product to maximize its per-period utility, subject to a standard budget constraint.Formally,

\operatorname*{max}_{c_{i}\ge0}\left\{a\log(c_{a,t}-\overline{{a}})+(1-a)\frac{1}{\rho}\log[b c_{m}^{\rho}+(1-b)(c_{s}+\overline{{s}})^{\rho}]\right\},

p_{a}c_{a}+p_{m}c_{m}+p_{s}c_{s}=w L+r(K_{a}+K_{m}+K_{s}),

Market clearing for labor requires that  

$$
L_{a}+L_{m}+L_{s}=L
$$  

The market for each good produced must clear the following:  

$$
c_{a}=Y_{a};c_{m}=Y_{m};c_{s}=Y_{s}.
$$

### 2.5. The impact of new and old technology on the equilibrium solution of thelaborstructure  

Over time, with the development of new and old technology, the share of labor in agriculture will reduce substantially, that is, with the technological improvement, the labor resources of agriculture will be transferred into services and industry. When time t tends to infinity, the technological level $\overline{{{A}}}_{a}A^{\gamma_{a}}$ and $\overline{{A}}_{s}\dot{A}^{\gamma_{s}}$ also tend to infinity, and the share of labor in agriculture converges to $a^{*}$ over the long run by (20). Similar to Kongsamut et al. (2001), the non-homotheticity of preference over agriculture and service goods $(\overline{{a}},\overline{{s}}>0)$ leads to labor moving away from agriculture in the process of structural change.  

The changes in the labor reallocation in industry are relatively complex. The technological progress rate of agriculture is generally the fastest (Young, 2003; Cao and Birchenall, 2013), so the molecular part of equation (21) tends to show a decreasing trend. The change in the denominator of equation (21) depends on the ratio $D$ of the TFP of industry and services and the substitution elasticity $\rho$ between industrial and service products. In the early stage of technological progress, the ratio changes relatively slowly, so the labor share in industry will increase during the early stage. As time goes on, $D(t)^{\frac{\rho}{1-\rho}}$ tends to infinity if $({\mu}_{s}-{\mu}_{m}){\rho}>0;$ 1 and there exists time $t^{*}$ , when $t~>~t^{*}$ ， $L_{m}$ decreases. The movement of the labor share when $t~>~t^{*}$ is very similar to Proposition 2 in Ngai and Pissarides (2007), which indicates that a high elasticity of substitution across manufacturing and service goods $(0~<~\rho~<~1)$ leads to shifts in the employment shares of sectors with high TFP growth $(\mu_{s}>\mu_{m})$  

Along the sectoral technology development process, the share of labor in services will increase constantly. The “crowding-out effect" of new and old technological progress on the labor resources of agriculture and the lower labor share of services during the early stage may make its ability to absorb labor resources stronger than that of industry. However, aftertime $t^{*}$ , the development of new technology will produce a "crowding-out effect" on the labor of agriculture and industry simultaneously, and the labor share of services will continue to grow.  

## 3. Data  

Considering that 1978-2018 is the key period in China's economic transformation and development since the reform and opening-up process, this paper will calibrate the parameters of the theoretical model according to this period to verify the theoretical analysis.  

### 3.1. Data source  

For our analysis, we calibrate the benchmark economy to Chinese labor market data from 1978 to 2018. The share of labor is calculated by using the number of employees of three sectors in China (at the end of the year). The data are drawn from the China Statistical Yearbook.  

We need to make clear and definite the development trend and level of the new generation of IT. We also need to select parameter values for $a^{*},\overline{{a}},\overline{{s}},\kappa$ and the parameter values that related to the technical level, $\mu_{a},\mu_{s},\gamma_{a},\gamma_{s},\mu_{d i f}$ and $\gamma_{d i f}$  

### 3.2. “S” technology diffusion curve  

We refer to the features of the new generation of IT industry in China and then deduce the value of relevant parameters through the realworld situation of China's industrial development. We can deduce the evolutionary track of the new generation of IT. We verify these parameter assumptions by fitting the benchmark model to the real-world situation in China.  

First, we normalize the new generation of IT levels across sectors to one in 1978. Based on the $^{\circ}\mathsf{S}\prime\prime$ technology diffusion curve proposed by Mansfield (1961), the relevant research results and the existing literature on the new generation of $\mathrm{IT}$ ,this paper uses equation (3) to describe the new generation of IT A(t). The initial value $A_{0}$ is standardized to 1, the curvature of the change trend of the technology progress growth rate is set to 0.25, that is, $\mu~=~0.25$ ,the time node of the change trend of the new technology progress growth rate from convex to concave is set as 2020, i.e., $h=2020$ , the time to popularize 5G in China, which can be regarded as an inflection point due to Shannon's law.2 The limit value of the new generation of IT $A^{*}$ is set to 4. Under the above assumptions, the development trend of the new generation of IT is shown in Fig. 2.  

We can see from Fig. 2 that the new generation of IT was approximately to one before 20oo. It can be considered that the development level of the new generation of IT before 2000 was low and had not been applied to all walks of life, so it had little impact on social and economic activities. The development of the new technology emerged in 2000 and was in the primary stage from 2000 to 2010. It entered a period of high-speed development around 2010, the time to popularize 4G in China. The technological level in 2020 is approximately 2.5, which is more than twice as high as that $1.2\mathrm{in}2010$ 3 This is also in line with the development trend of the new generation of IT represented by big data, artificial intelligence, mobile internet, etc. Especially in recent years, the development of the new generation of IT has been widely concerned and valued by the international community and the corresponding policy support; the supporting scientific and technological innovation achievements have been increasing. At the same time, the development of this new IT and the benefits brought by its application also have great attraction to the manufacturers, so that it can be promoted and applied in a wider range, then it can develop rapidly in recentyears.  

We assume that the development of the new generation of IT in China may enter a bottleneck period around 2040, thus changing from “new technology” to “old technology." According to the hypothesis of the model, the “old technology” will develop at a constant rate without stagnation, which means that in 20 years, the progress rate of the new generation of IT may be very small but greater than zero, and the new generation of IT will show a slow development trend, but not a complete stop, it may show a steady state of development.

In this model, the parameter values need to be calibrated are: $a^{*}$ ， ${\overline{{a}}},$ $\overline{{s}},\kappa$ and the parameters that related to the technical level, $\mu_{a},\mu_{s}$ ， $\gamma_{a},\gamma_{s}$ ， and $\mu_{d i f}~=~[(\mu_{s}~-~\mu_{m})\rho]/(1~-~\rho)$ and $\gamma_{d i f}=[(\gamma_{s}-\gamma_{m})\rho]/(1-\rho);$ which can represent the technical level differences. Because agriculture is land-intensive, industry is capital-intensive, and service is human-capital-intensive, the contribution of the new generation of IT among the three sectors differs (Bartel et al., 2007; Helm,2020; Gillman, 2021). The development of IT has liberated some parts of the agricultural labor force, but the agricultural sector is landintensive and highly dependent on land resources. Factors such as the state, endowment, mode, and relevant policies and systems of land use will also restrict and guide the direction of regional industrial development and structural adjustment. The traditional advantages of laborintensive industries are gradually weakened, and the degree of labor agglomeration has decreased. Thus, the industry has gradually completed the transformation of old and new technologies, invested a lot of capital to upgrade equipment, and replaced manpower with machines. Thefact that $\gamma_{s}$ is the highest means that the new generation of IT has the fastest development and widest range of application in the services sector. The application of the new generation of IT in services mainly takes place through a combination of knowledge, learning, and innovation of human capital to better enable the new technology to play its role, promote the transformation of innovative achievements, and provide intelligent services for daily production and life. Because the new industry is assumed to have a relatively higher human capital factor share, as human capital deepening occurs, labor shifts toward the new industry and away from traditional industries (Gillman, 2021). However, because industry and agriculture are capital-intensive and landintensive, respectively, the combination of the new generation of IT and the two sectors is relatively weak (Bartel et al., 2007; Helm, 2020). This shows that the contribution of the new generation of IT to these two sectors is also relatively low. From the results of parameter calibration, the technological progress rate for agriculture is the highest from 1978 to 2000, which is consistent with the conclusions of existing research. Fan and Zhang (2002) estimated that the TFP of agriculture from 1979 to 1997 was about 0.033; the numerical difference is due to different estimation methods and different sample periods.

### 3.4. Results analysis  

Before 2010, the new generation of IT is in the primary stage of development. From 2010, IT has developed vigorously and has been widely promoted and applied. Accordingly, it can be seen from Fig. 3 that in recent years the share of labor has also changed significantly, specifically, the share of labor in agriculture has been declining rapidly, and the share of labor in services has been increasing significantly. This is in accordance with the development trend of China's new generation of IT and the process of the transformation of labor structure across sectors.  

For agriculture, as Engel's law tests, with the rapid development of China's economy and the improvement of residents’ income level, the proportion of food consumption is declining, which has been confirmed in relevant statistical studies. The demand of households for agricultural products is relatively stable, while the original technological progress rate of agriculture is higher than that of industry and services. Under the condition that output (demand) is relatively constant, technological progress will promote the reallocation of labor in agriculture to industry and services, resulting in a stable downward trend of the labor share in agriculture in a ladder form from 1978 to 2000. After 2000, especially after 2010, the increased penetration of the new generation of IT, such as big data, artificial intelligence, and mobile internet, into traditional agriculture has greatly promoted automation, scale, and intelligent production and greatly improved the TFP of agriculture. Therefore the "substitution effect" generated by technological progress has become increasingly obvious. After 2010, the decline in the labor share in agriculture compared to the previous period is obviously faster, and many labor resources are transferred into industry and services.

## 4. Discussion on robustness  

We now turn to an analysis intended to assess the robustness of the model along two key dimensions. It is useful to provide the punchline first: the model results are robust, and the test results of the evidence vary little. We focus on two sets of considerations: labor market distortions and structural production differences. In the benchmark model, some assumptions are not consistent with the reality of China's economy. For example, our model abstracts from the labor flow barrier between different sectors, so we assume that wages in the three sectors are the same. In fact, the average wage of labor in industry and services is much higher than that in agriculture. In the benchmark model, to obtain the expression of the labor share of the three sectors in a simple form, this paper assumes that the elasticity of labor input to the output of industry and services is equal, that is, that $\alpha_{m}~=~\alpha_{s}$ .This section attempts to relax these assumptions and compares the numerical simulation results with the benchmark model results.  

### 4.1.Labor market distortions  

We first explore the robustness of the model by altering the wages among different sectors. Considering that China, as the largest developing country, has practical factors such as an imperfect labor market system and market distortions, which will lower the labor wage level in agriculture, the reallocation cost of labor from agriculture to nonagricultural sectors may increase due to the existence of labor flow barriers or market distortions. Therefore, this paper uses the labor wage ratio, $\theta$ ，of agricultural and non-agricultural sectors to describe the increased flow cost. If the wage in industry and services is equal, which is recorded as $w_{\cdot}$ the wage in agriculture is $(1-\theta)w$ . In this case, it is only necessary to replace $\alpha_{a}$ with $\alpha_{a}^{\prime}=\alpha/(1-\theta)$ in the above model. In the new numerical simulation experiment, setting $\theta~=~0.25$ ,when $\alpha_{a}=0.6$ and $\alpha_{s}=0.4$ , we can obtain $\alpha_{a}^{\prime}=0.8$ , and $a^{*}$ is from 0.05 to 0.095. The increasing of $\alpha_{a}^{\prime}$ and $a^{*}$ is also due to labor flow barriers or market distortions. Since the labor mobility cost in agriculture explains the existence of labor mobility barriers, the labor resources among the three sectors do not flow easily. It can be found that the wage distortion of agriculture only changes its ultimate labor share, while other parameters remain unchanged. Table 2 summarizes the changes in the share of labor when wage differences are considered. Similar treatment can be done for the capital distortion of agriculture by changing the value of $a^{*}$ accordingly.  

Table 2 presents the evidence, reporting the results in terms of the effect of different sectoral wages. Considering labor market distortions in the three sectors, there is much less reallocation of labor away from agriculture into services than in the benchmark model. However, if we increase the penetration rate of new technology in agriculture, $\gamma_{a}$ from 0.55 to 0.80, the model performs well. Thus, the benchmark model will underestimate the sector-specific penetration of new technology if we consider market distortions. The overall trend of structural labor change after considering wage differences is not that significant, that is, the results still match the general trend in China's labor share change, which indicates that the simulation results of the benchmark model are stable and reliable.  

### 4.2. Structural production differences  

We then assess the robustness of the model to considering different production structures. In the classical literature on the impact of technology progress on economic growth and structural change, most of them assume that the labor and capital input structure in the production functions of the three sectors are the same, except for the different technological progress rates (Kongsamut et al., 2001; Ngai and Pissarides, 2007; Duarte and Restuccia, 2010). Based on the benchmark model, this assumption has been relaxed. To obtain a relatively simple explicit expression of the labor share, we assume $\alpha_{m}~=~\alpha_{s}$ in the benchmark model, that is, that the input structure of factors in industry and services is the same, and that the factor input structure in agriculture differs from that of industry and services. To further discuss the robustness of the benchmark model, we change this assumption in the new numerical experiment and assume that the contribution rate of labor factors to the output in services is greater than that in industry.

Therefore, we design and perform the following two sets of counterfactuals to discuss and answer the preceding questions.

### 5.2. The role of old technological progress  

TFP differences across sectors have been seen as an important driver promoting structural change (Ngai and Pissarides, 2007; Acemoglu and Guerrieri, 2008; Mao and Yao, 2012). Although we focus more on the important role of the new generation of IT, old technology progress should not be ignored. In this subsection, we aim to illustrate the role of old technology progress using comparative analysis. We show the results of two different scenarios in Figs. 5 and 6.  

It can be seen in Fig. 5 that when there is no penetration of the new generation of IT, the labor reallocation will still progress, but the variation in the labor share will be relatively small.  

The trend displayed in Fig. 6 shows that when the progress rate of old technology in the three sectors increase by $50\%$ ,and allelse equal, the variation in the labor share is significant. Compared to Fig. 6, we can conclude that structural change will still go on with the old technology progress.  

### 5.3. The role of the new generation of IT in structural labor change

## 6. Concluding remarks  

We explore the role of the new generation of $\mathrm{IT}$ in theprocess of structural labor transformation in China. Using Chinese labor market data from 1978 to 2018, we find that the rapid development and widespread use of the new generation of IT since 20o0 can accelerate the process of China's structural labor adjustment. The benchmark model explains the rapid decline of the labor share in agriculture and the sharp increase of the labor share in services in recent years. The non-homothetic preference of the sector family for agricultural products leads to a relatively stable demand for agricultural products, while the sharp increase of the TFP in agriculture brought by the new generation of IT will lead to an outflow of labor from agriculture. The higher penetration rate of new technology into services leads to a higher contribution of new technology to TFP growth than that of industry, so ser. vices has a better ability to absorb labor and the share of labor increases significantly.  

The robustness tests show that the slight distortions in the market structure and the slight differences in the production structure have no significant effect on the change in China's labor structure. Our analysis on the robustness tests, with a particular emphasis on differences in production structure, extends the previous literature, which has mainly focused on different sectoral technological levels while ignoring factor input structural differences.  

Further counterfactual experiments show that labor reallocation across sectors is driven by two channels: income effects due to nonhomothetic preferences and substitution effects due to differential productivity growth across sectors. The technological progress rate is the main driver for adjustments in the labor structure. The new generation of IT has played an important role in the process of structural labor adjustments in recent years. Compared to the experiment of maintaining the original technological level, the emergence of the new generation of IT has promoted changes in the labor structure. In the short term, an improvement in the progress rate of the new generation of IT may speed up the adjustment in China's labor structure. However, in the long run, the improvement of the space of the progress of the new generation of IT and an increase in the penetration rate of the three sectorsmaygreatlypromotetheoptimizationofChina'slabor structure, which is characterized by a significant decline in the labor share in agriculture, accompanied by a significant increase in the labor share in services. In the long run, the labor share in agriculture will be significantly lower than that in the benchmark model,and the share of labor in services will be significantly higher than that of the benchmark model.  

Our findings provide a richer picture of the relation between the rapid development of the new generation of IT and the adjustment of the labor structure. It also provides several suggestions for policy. Making full use of the new generation of IT to transform traditional sectors, deepening the integrated application of IT in various sectors, and increasing its penetration rate in various sectors for enterprises seem necessary and constructive. In the process of formulating and implementing industrial policies, government departments should strongly encourage and support the innovation, research, and development of a new generation of IT and give full play to its role in promoting structural labor adjustments.  

Possible areas for further research, parallel to the solution offers discussed above, include the following. The theoretical model of this paper can be extended from a single-period equilibrium model to an intertemporal consumption model, so that the economic growth problem can be investigated. In the future, we can endogenize the capital accumulation process and investigate the role of capital to better explain quantitatively the change in the labor structure during this development process. In addition, based on the study of the impact of the new generation of IT on the labor share, we can consider the impact of new technology on unbalanced economic growth. We can also investigate the role of sectoral labor productivity in explaining the process of wage structure and economic growth.
